qas.question: When did human rights for Aboriginal people begin to improve?

answers.text: The second half of the 20th century

qas.question: What year was constitutional discrimination ended?
What else was included in the 1967 referendum?

answers.text: to include Aborigines in the national census.

qas.question: What term was embraced during this period?
Who said the Aboriginal people started to embrace their ancestry?

context: <a0_0>The second half of the 20th century<a0_0/> to the present has seen a gradual shift towards improved human rights for Aboriginal people. In a <a1_0>1967<a1_0/> referendum over 90% of the Australian population voted to end constitutional discrimination and <a2_0>to include Aborigines in the national census.<a2_0/> During this period many Aboriginal activists began to embrace the term <a3_0>"black"<a3_0/> and use their ancestry as a source of pride. <a4_0>Activist Bob Maza<a4_0/> said:
